semantic_title: Use of External Cause Codes with Burns and Corrosions for Source, Intent, and Place Documentation
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Injury, Poisoning, and Certain Other Consequences of External Causes > d. Burns and Corrosions > 9. Use of an external cause code with burns and corrosions

content.full_text: An external cause code should be used with burns and corrosions to identify the source and intent of the burn, as well as the place where it occurred. (Evidence: pg no: 82, L30-L31)
content.summary: Requirement to use external cause codes with burns and corrosions to document the source, intent, and place of occurrence (Evidence: pg no: 82, L30-L31)
key_concepts: External cause code requirement (Evidence: pg no: 82, L30)
Place of occurrence (Evidence: pg no: 82, L31)

detailed_rules.rule_text: External cause codes should be used with burns and corrosions (Evidence: pg no: 82, L30-L31)
detailed_rules.explanation: External cause codes provide essential information about the source, intent, and location of the burn or corrosion incident (Evidence: pg no: 82, L30-L31)

detailed_rules.rule_text: External cause codes should identify source, intent, and place of occurrence (Evidence: pg no: 82, L31)
detailed_rules.explanation: Complete external cause coding requires documentation of what caused the burn (source), whether it was accidental or intentional (intent), and where it happened (place) (Evidence: pg no: 82, L31)
